physical_findings: Interstitial keratitis (unilateral or bilateral corneal stromal inflammation, immune-mediated, non-ulcerative, non-suppurative, leading to neovascularization and scarring)
Cataracts (most likely due to uveal inflammation)
Conjunctivitis (mild in secondary syphilis, sarcoidosis-like with granulomas possible)
Episcleritis (isolated, more common in secondary syphilis)
Scleritis (isolated, more common in tertiary syphilis, nodular or diffuse)
Uveitis (panuveitis most common in HIV-positive patients, posterior uveitis predominant in HIV-negative patients)

Retinitis (necrotizing or non-necrotizing, in macula, midperiphery, and peripheral retina; may be confluent, associated with vasculitis and vascular occlusion; slowly progressive, responds to penicillin; placoid confluent lesions possible)
Exudative retinal detachment (uncommon, associated with retinal infiltrates)

Retinal detachment (tractional and rhegmatogenous, rarely complicating syphilitic uveitis; often complicated by early proliferative vitreoretinopathy; retinal breaks associated with prior retinitis; poor visual outcomes)
risk_factors: Congenital transmission of syphilis in utero (transplacentally or during delivery)
HIV co-infection (increases risk and severity of ocular syphilis)

required: Clinical findings consistent with early congenital syphilitic oculopathy (e.g., interstitial keratitis, cataracts, uveitis, retinitis)
Positive serological tests for syphilis (nontreponemal and treponemal)
supportive: Imaging findings consistent with syphilitic ocular involvement

differential_diagnoses: Other causes of retinitis (e.g., acute retinal necrosis, progressive outer retinal necrosis)
